Award.AwardTitle: Questions on Local Cohomology and Tight Closure Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is concerned with several questions in commutative algebra. This is a field that studies solution sets of polynomial equations. Understanding solution sets of polynomial equations is of fundamental importance in many sciences, in engineering, and in other disciplines as well. Most of the questions that will be investigated deal with the nature of the solution sets: some are questions that have been unresolved for a number of years, but for which recent advances provide the likelihood of a solution; others arise naturally from new developments in the area. A number of projects are connected with local cohomology theory: this theory often provides the best answers to basic questions such as the least number of polynomials needed to define a solution set.

The projects on local cohomology theory include algorithmic aspects, as well as structural properties such as support and injective dimension. There is a special focus on local cohomology modules of polynomial rings and hypersurfaces over the integers: this stems from the fact that there is a canonical homomorphism from the integers to any ring, and this makes local cohomology modules over the integers, in a sense, universal; this viewpoint has proved useful in recent work of the PI and collaborators. The project will also investigate local cohomology over the integers. The research will further develop the connections of local cohomology with prime characteristic numerical invariants such as the F-pure threshold, and will study the composition series of local cohomology modules over rings of differential operators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polynomial equations arise quite naturally in a wide number of applications. One of the most fruitful approaches to the study of solutions sets of families of polynomial equations has been via studying polynomial functions on these solution sets; the collection of such functions forms what is known as a commutative ring, and their study is the area of mathematics known as commutative algebra. The flexibility offered by this approach via commutative rings enables one to gather information about solutions sets over the complex numbers by analyzing, instead, solutions over finite fields.


Several of the projects pursued are connected with the theory of local cohomology. Local cohomology modules are algebraic structures associated with commutative rings that carry a tremendous amount of information. They have applications to basic yet deep questions such as determining the minimum number of polynomial equations needed to define the solution set of a large family of polynomials. One of the PI's long-term projects has been studying the interplay between local cohomology modules over the complex numbers and over finite fields; substantial progress has been made in this direction in joint work with Bhatt, Blickle, Lyubeznik, and Zhang.


In a different direction, in collaboration with Conca, Mostafazadehfard, and Varbaro, the PI has been investigating Hankel determinantal rings; these are linear specializations of certain classical invariant rings, that arise as the commutative rings associated with secant varieties of rational normal curves. While these have been studied from various points of view for over 80 years, some basic questions regarding Hankel determinantal rings were answered only recently in the collaborative work.


The PI mentored postdoctoral researchers and graduate students in commutative algebra during the grant period, and also supervised a master's thesis in cryptography. In addition to talks at various conferences, the PI presented lecture series at six international instructional schools. He was an organizer for week-long workshops at the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute, Berkeley, The University of Utah, and the Centro Internazionale Matematico Estivo, Trento, Italy.
